title: Baraka Economics Check-in
format_note: Voice conversation - audio transcriptions via ChatGPT voice mode

beliefs.claim: Bilal has been working on 'Baraka Economics' book but neglected it for a while - book scope expanded from economics to meaning, epistemology, Western world missing faculty of perception beyond materialism - now 'floundering' on themes and struggling to re-engage
beliefs.reasoning: First message: 'Can we work on a check-in right now for the Baraka Economics book that I've been working on? I feel like I've really neglected it.' Then: 'I started with this idea of economics but then I wound up talking about meaning and epistemology... I think I got a little lost.' Shows: project exists, stalled, scope creep, seeking clarity.

evidence.quote: Can we work on a check-in right now for the Baraka Economics book that I've been working on? I feel like I've really neglected it for a while
evidence.speaker: user

evidence.quote: I'm still sort of floundering in between thinking about like what to write about, what are the themes, what are the topics. I started with this idea of economics but then I wound up talking about meaning and epistemology
evidence.speaker: user

evidence.quote: I think I got a little lost and I'm trying to get unlost right now
evidence.speaker: user

beliefs.claim: Bilal believes Western world is missing 'a faculty of perception that includes the heart or includes a way of thinking that isn't simply materialistic' - there are 'messages from an unseen realm that are reliable and true' accessible through 'inner knowing'
beliefs.reasoning: Core thesis of Baraka Economics: 'the Western world missing a faculty of perception that includes the heart or includes a way of thinking that isn't simply materialistic.' Later: 'we can actually agree that we have messages from an unseen realm that are reliable and true.' This is the EPISTEMOLOGICAL claim - another way of knowing beyond rationalist materialism.

evidence.quote: the idea of the Western world missing a faculty of perception that includes the heart or includes a way of thinking that isn't simply materialistic
evidence.speaker: user

evidence.quote: is it crazy to think that we can actually agree that we have messages from an unseen realm that are reliable and true
evidence.speaker: user

evidence.quote: there is a way of attending to the world when we are really literate in our sources of meaning... we have an access to a knowing that we are beholden to
evidence.speaker: user

beliefs.claim: Bilal has tension between 'dreaming big' and 'actually doing something' - wants work that's 'valuable for my career' and 'important thing for me to do' but struggles with execution and clarity - asks 'What's something that I'll actually do? Not something I'll just talk about'
beliefs.reasoning: Explicit: 'I don't want to just dream big. I want to actually do something.' And: 'What's the engaged way of producing the Betaconomics book... What's something that I'll actually do? Not something I'll just talk about.' Shows awareness of pattern: big ideas, low execution. Needs practical path forward, not more philosophizing.

evidence.quote: I don't want to just dream big. I want to actually do something. How can I move forward from here?
evidence.speaker: user

evidence.quote: What's the engaged way of producing the Betaconomics book? Like, you know me best... What's something that I'll actually do? You know, not something I'll just talk about
evidence.speaker: user

evidence.quote: I'm trying to figure out whether or not philosophical writing is actually helpful for anybody, or if I should actually just be more practical
evidence.speaker: user

beliefs.claim: Bilal is in crisis about Bloom (8 years of work) - at impact conference handed out 'kindness kiwis' cards instead of pitching Bloom because 'I don't have clarity and I just don't know what to do anymore' - questioning 'the vision that I've been putting forth into the world with this social enterprise accelerator and what do I still believe in'
beliefs.reasoning: VULNERABLE admission: 'I was recently at an impact conference and all I did was hand out these cards for kindness kiwis instead of pitching people on what Bloom is doing. If I pitch people on what Bloom is doing, we might be making money... but I just couldn't get myself to do it because I don't have clarity and I just don't know what to do anymore.' 8 years, can't pitch it. Identity/vision crisis.

evidence.quote: I was recently at an impact conference and all I did was hand out these cards for kindness kiwis instead of pitching people on what Bloom is doing
evidence.speaker: user

evidence.quote: I just couldn't get myself to do it because I don't have clarity and I just don't know what to do anymore
evidence.speaker: user

evidence.quote: I'm trying to figure out what is the vision that I've been putting forth into the world with this social enterprise accelerator and what do I still believe in
evidence.speaker: user

beliefs.claim: Bilal diagnoses culture wars as rooted in postmodern worldview ('there's nothing true and that everything is a debate') - believes 'you can't have a strong why in this postmodern worldview' because postmodernism is 'all about doubt and subjectivity' - 'How can universities encourage meaning construction without an arena that is meaningful?'
beliefs.reasoning: Cultural diagnosis: 'A lot of it is related to this postmodern idea that there's nothing true and that everything is a debate, and that debate turns into a fight, rather than people seeking truth.' Then connects to meaning crisis: 'How can we have a strong why in this postmodern worldview?' This is Jordan Peterson territory but from Islamic/spiritual perspective.

evidence.quote: A lot of it is related to this postmodern idea that there's nothing true and that everything is a debate, and that debate turns into a fight, rather than people seeking truth
evidence.speaker: user

evidence.quote: A postmodern worldview is one that is all about doubt and subjectivity. How can we have a strong why in this postmodern worldview?
evidence.speaker: user

evidence.quote: How can all these universities that are engaging in constructing these postmodern worldviews... be encouraging meaning construction without an arena that is meaningful?
evidence.speaker: user

beliefs.claim: Bilal uses Joe Edelman's Meaning Framework which says 'a meaningful moment grabs us... our attention is being pulled... not us deciding what is meaningful' - 'there is something else deciding what is meaningful for us' - this provides 'systematic way of describing meaning'
beliefs.reasoning: Explains Joe's framework: 'the interesting thing about Joe Edelman's Meaning Framework is that there's a moment where meaning is not a choice... a meaningful moment grabs us. We are taken by, we are grabbed, our attention is being pulled into something.' This is CORE to Come Alive - attention policies describe what grabs you. Bilal sees this as evidence of 'unseen realm' - attention drawn not self-directed.

evidence.quote: the interesting thing about Joe Edelman's Meaning Framework is that there's a moment where meaning is not a choice. It's not something, a meaningful moment grabs us. We are taken by, we are grabbed, our attention is being pulled into something. It's not us deciding what is meaningful for us, but there is something else deciding what is meaningful for us
evidence.speaker: user

evidence.quote: I've been using Joe Edelman's Meaning Framework, which allows us to begin that process to have a sort of systematic way of describing meaning
evidence.speaker: user

beliefs.claim: Bilal is going to WellBeing Project conference in 3 weeks (mid-May 2025) - wants to bring 'maybe it's not the book, maybe it's a paper, maybe it's an article' connecting flourishing, worldview, and classroom education
beliefs.reasoning: Specific deadline: 'I'm going to a conference in a few weeks... I want to be sure that I'm prepared for bringing something with me. Maybe it's not the book, maybe it's a paper, maybe it's an article.' WellBeing Network 'trying to bring flourishing into the classroom.' This is PRACTICAL deliverable vs. abstract book.

evidence.quote: I'm going to a conference in a few weeks. And I want to be sure that I'm prepared for bringing something with me. Maybe it's not the book, maybe it's a paper, maybe it's an article that we can have as a discussion
evidence.speaker: user

evidence.quote: It's a WellBeing Network that's trying to bring flourishing into the classroom
evidence.speaker: user

evidence.quote: if there is a way of maybe making a small project that can bring all this together for that moment that's happening in three weeks
evidence.speaker: user

beliefs.claim: Bilal is a graduate of Learning Planet Institute in Paris - founder asked him for collaboration ideas for their 20th anniversary - considers using worldview/flourishing survey there
beliefs.reasoning: New affiliation: 'I'm also a part of the Learning Planet Institute in Paris. I'm a graduate, and they have their 20th anniversary of the school coming up, and the founder asked me if I have any ideas of what we can do together.' Shows: international network, educational institutions, active collaboration requests.

evidence.quote: I'm also a part of the Learning Planet Institute in Paris. I'm a graduate, and they have their 20th anniversary of the school coming up, and the founder asked me if I have any ideas of what we can do together
evidence.speaker: user

beliefs.claim: Bilal believes inner knowing is like 'Buddhists and Zen practitioners' who have 'repeatable and reliable experiments that you can do with inner observation that is then proven over time' - wants to create similar experiment for Western/academic context
beliefs.reasoning: Draws on contemplative traditions: 'Buddhists and Zen practitioners and others have this sort of repeatable and reliable experiments that you can do with inner observation that is then proven over time. So I'm wondering if we can create another sort of experiment similar to these types of experiments.' Trying to make 'inner knowing' empirically credible like meditation research.

evidence.quote: Buddhists and Zen practitioners and others have this sort of repeatable and reliable experiments that you can do with inner observation that is then proven over time. So I'm wondering if we can create another sort of experiment similar to these types of experiments
evidence.speaker: user

beliefs.claim: Bilal believes 'there is such thing as truth and goodness, and that we have access to it in our quiet, still states that are not necessarily emotional' - distinguishes 'difference between an emotion and a feeling and an inner knowing' - truth accessible through contemplative states
beliefs.reasoning: Metaphysical claim: 'there is such thing as truth and goodness, and that we have access to it in our quiet, still states that are not necessarily emotional, like there's a difference between an emotion and a feeling and an inner knowing.' This is core Islamic epistemology (qalb/heart knowledge) but trying to articulate for secular/academic context.

evidence.quote: there is such thing as truth and goodness, and that we have access to it in our quiet, still states that are not necessarily emotional, like there's a difference between an emotion and a feeling and an inner knowing
evidence.speaker: user

values_cards.title: Integrating Fragmented Life's Work
attention_policies: PROJECTS that all seem to point toward one deeper question (Baraka Economics, Come Alive, Bloom, WellBeing conferences)
MOMENTS of clarity about 'what's the point of life anyway?' that transcend specific projects
TENSIONS between dreaming big vs. actually doing something useful
FRAMEWORKS that provide systematic ways to describe meaning (Joe Edelman's approach)
DEADLINES that force synthesis (3-week conference, 20th anniversary collaboration)

quotes: I'm also working on the Come Alive framework, and I'm wondering if all of these things sort of come together and what like a higher order principle or conversation I might be actually having
all of these questions are seeming to kind of not connect to one of the core questions that I have, which is around, what's the point of life anyway?
I don't want to just dream big. I want to actually do something
can you connect the entire project with the other projects that I'm working on and maybe make a table showing how the different principles connect across them?
stories: Started Baraka Economics book on economics, ended up in meaning and epistemology
At impact conference, handed out kindness kiwis cards instead of pitching Bloom (8 years of work)
WellBeing conference in 3 weeks - needs deliverable that integrates everything
Learning Planet Institute asking for collaboration ideas
Asking ChatGPT to help find 'higher order principle' connecting all projects

tensions: Multiple projects (Baraka Economics, Bloom, Come Alive, WellBeing work) vs. single coherent vision
Philosophical depth (meaning, epistemology) vs. practical career value
Dreaming big vs. actually executing on deliverables
8 years into Bloom but can't pitch it anymore - vision crisis
values_cards.note: Low energy - this is CRISIS conversation. Bilal is lost, floundering, seeking clarity.

values_cards.title: Articulating Non-Materialist Epistemology for Western Context
attention_policies: WAYS OF KNOWING beyond rationalist materialism (heart, inner knowing, unseen realm)
LANGUAGE that makes contemplative knowing credible to academics ('repeatable experiments' like Buddhism/Zen)
CULTURAL DIAGNOSES like postmodernism's meaning crisis ('how can we have a strong why?')
PHENOMENOLOGY of attention being drawn not self-directed (Joe Edelman's framework)
MOMENTS that 'take your breath away' or you 'couldn't take your eyes off' - involuntary attention capture

quotes: the Western world missing a faculty of perception that includes the heart or includes a way of thinking that isn't simply materialistic
is it crazy to think that we can actually agree that we have messages from an unseen realm that are reliable and true
a meaningful moment grabs us... our attention is being pulled... not us deciding what is meaningful
Buddhists and Zen practitioners have repeatable and reliable experiments with inner observation
there is such thing as truth and goodness, and we have access to it in our quiet, still states
stories: Trying to articulate 'inner knowing' for academic survey
Researching who else is doing work on inner observation as scientific inquiry (Ken Wilber mentioned)
Exploring how Come Alive framework shows attention being drawn (not chosen)
Connecting worldview/cosmology to meaning construction and flourishing

tensions: Islamic epistemology (qalb/heart knowledge) vs. secular academic language
Spiritual truth claims vs. scientific credibility
values_cards.note: HIGH energy when discussing epistemology - this is the CORE intellectual project

values_cards.title: Using AI as Voice Coach for Thinking Through Complexity
attention_policies: VOICE MODE conversations that allow rambling, exploration, following tangents
REQUESTS for coaching ('ask me one question at a time', 'navigate a decision tree')
PROMPTS that leverage AI's memory ('you know me best', 'review everything we've done together')
FORMATS that force synthesis (tables connecting projects, abstracts for papers, survey templates)
CLARIFICATION requests ('say it like I'm five, like I'm a high schooler, like I'm a PhD researcher')

quotes: Can you ask me one question at a time and sort of navigate a decision tree or a thought tree? Or, you know, treat me like a coach would
you have a lot of information about me in your memory and in our history. So, review everything that we've done together
you know me best, and you have a lot of context on me from the Come Alive framework... What's something that I'll actually do?
First, explain what I'm trying to do and clarify my language for me. I don't feel like I've been able to articulate it clearly initially
stories: 30-message voice conversation (over 30 minutes) working through Baraka Economics crisis
Asks ChatGPT to review all projects and create integration table
Requests survey templates, paper abstracts, research questions
Uses 'say it like I'm five / high schooler / PhD' to test clarity of concepts

values_cards.note: Voice mode enables different kind of thinking - verbal processing, not written. More personal, vulnerable.

book_material.claim: Baraka Economics book started as economics, became about 'Western world missing faculty of perception that includes the heart or includes a way of thinking that isn't simply materialistic' - epistemological critique from Islamic perspective
book_material.why_book_worthy: This IS Book D (Islamic Values in Secular/Tech Work). The core thesis: Western epistemology is incomplete - missing qalb (heart knowledge), contemplative knowing, 'messages from unseen realm.' Bilal trying to articulate Islamic epistemology for academic/secular context. CRITICAL for Book D. Also connects to Book A (Integrated Approach) - how to live with multiple ways of knowing.

book_material.claim: Bloom vision crisis after 8 years: at impact conference, handed out 'kindness kiwis' cards instead of pitching Bloom because 'I don't have clarity and I just don't know what to do anymore'
book_material.why_book_worthy: VULNERABLE admission of organizational/identity crisis. After 8 years building Bloom, can't pitch it anymore. Why? Vision misalignment. Conv 8 (2023 Nur Coop) shows authentic values (Good Globalization, baraka). THIS (2025) shows: those values don't align with 'social enterprise accelerator' framing. Can't sell what you don't believe in. Book A - navigating integrity vs. organizational demands.

book_material.claim: Postmodern meaning crisis diagnosis: 'postmodern worldview is all about doubt and subjectivity. How can we have a strong why in this postmodern worldview? How can universities encourage meaning construction without an arena that is meaningful?'
book_material.why_book_worthy: Cultural diagnosis connecting postmodernism → meaning crisis → culture wars. Similar to Jordan Peterson but from Islamic/spiritual angle. Universities teaching postmodern subjectivity while trying to foster wellbeing/flourishing - contradiction. Book D or F (Cross-Cultural Education) - critique of Western educational epistemology.

book_material.claim: Joe Edelman's Meaning Framework insight: 'a meaningful moment grabs us... our attention is being pulled... not us deciding what is meaningful for us, but there is something else deciding' - evidence of 'unseen realm'
book_material.why_book_worthy: Bilal reads Come Alive framework through Islamic lens: attention capture = divine guidance. 'Something else' directing attention = messages from unseen realm. This is INTEGRATION of secular framework (Joe's) with spiritual worldview (Islamic). Book A (Integrated Approach) - how Bilal synthesizes across traditions. Book D - Islamic perspective on meaning.

book_material.claim: Execution vs. dreaming tension: 'I don't want to just dream big. I want to actually do something. What's something that I'll actually do? Not something I'll just talk about.'
book_material.why_book_worthy: Self-awareness of pattern: big ideas, low follow-through. Connects to Conv 1 (procrastination), Conv 3 (Parliaments - building execution systems). THIS shows: still struggling in 2025. Book A - how Bilal manages this tension. What works? What doesn't? Integration across conversations shows evolution.

book_material.claim: Voice AI coaching for complex thinking: 30+ minute voice conversation using ChatGPT as thinking partner - 'treat me like a coach would', 'review everything we've done together', 'you know me best'
book_material.why_book_worthy: NEW way of working with AI. Not text prompts but voice coaching sessions. Bilal uses AI's memory + conversational context to work through complex integration problems. Book E (AI for Social Good) or G (Portfolio) - case study in human-AI collaboration for meaning-making and decision support.

analysis_notes.context: April 28, 2025 - Voice conversation (30+ messages, 30+ minutes audio) working through Baraka Economics book crisis. Bilal 'floundering' - started with economics, ended up in meaning/epistemology about Western world missing heart-based perception. Core question: 'what's the point of life anyway?' Bloom crisis: 8 years in, can't pitch it anymore, handed out 'kindness kiwis' at impact conference instead. Trying to integrate: Baraka Economics + Come Alive framework + Bloom + WellBeing Project conference (3 weeks) + Learning Planet Institute collaboration. Asking ChatGPT to coach him through synthesis and find 'higher order principle.'
analysis_notes.key_insight: This is INTEGRATION CRISIS conversation. Bilal has multiple projects (Baraka Economics book, Bloom, Come Alive, WellBeing work, Learning Planet) but no coherent vision connecting them. Core intellectual project emerging: epistemology beyond Western materialism - 'faculty of perception that includes the heart', 'messages from unseen realm', 'inner knowing' validated through contemplative practice like Buddhism/Zen. This is Islamic epistemology (qalb/heart knowledge) for secular academic context. Cultural diagnosis: postmodern subjectivity undermines meaning construction → universities can't foster flourishing without coherent worldview. But PRACTICAL tension: wants career value + execution, not just philosophical dreaming. Voice AI coaching as thinking partnership - different from text prompts. More vulnerable, exploratory.
analysis_notes.cross_conversation_patterns: Conv 3 (Dec 2024 Barakanomics Business Philosophy): Earlier Baraka Economics work. THIS (April 2025): Follow-up check-in, still struggling. Conv 1 (Procrastination, 2023): Execution vs. dreaming tension. THIS: SAME tension 2 years later. Conv 4 (PTG research, 2024): Academic research. THIS: Trying to make inner knowing academically credible. Conv 8 (Nur Coop, 2023): Good Globalization values, baraka in commerce. THIS: Can't pitch Bloom anymore because misaligned with those values. Conv 6 (March 2023 self-analysis): Using meaning cards/Come Alive. THIS: Sees Joe's framework as evidence of 'unseen realm.' ADHD pattern: Multiple simultaneous projects, difficulty integrating. Book D taking shape: Islamic epistemology + Western materialism critique + contemplative validation.
questions_for_later_convos: Did Bilal complete a paper/article for the WellBeing conference in 3 weeks?
What happened with Learning Planet Institute 20th anniversary collaboration?
Did the worldview/flourishing survey get implemented?
What are 'kindness kiwis' cards? Related to Come Alive?
Did Baraka Economics book ever get published or abandoned?
How did Bloom crisis resolve? Still running in 2025?
Who did Bilal interview for the inner knowing research?
What's the 'higher order principle' connecting all projects?
Did voice AI coaching become regular practice or one-off?
How does Islamic qalb (heart) knowledge map to Joe Edelman's attention policies?
analysis_notes.connection_to_previous: Timeline: March 2023 (Conv 6, using meaning cards) → May 2024 (Conv 4, PTG research on spirituality + entrepreneurship) → Dec 2024 (Conv 11, values reflection app; Conv 12, organizational evaluation) → April 2025 (THIS). The arc: 2023 - using frameworks. 2024 - researching spirituality academically. Late 2024 - building tech tools. Early 2025 - CRISIS trying to integrate everything. Baraka Economics theme consistent but evolving: Conv 3 (Dec 2024) = business philosophy. THIS (April 2025) = epistemology + meaning crisis. Getting more philosophical, less practical - which creates tension with 'I want to actually DO something.' Voice format NEW - previous convos all text.
analysis_notes.timeline_marker: April 28, 2025 - Baraka Economics book check-in, Bloom vision crisis, integration struggle across multiple projects
analysis_notes.format_note: Voice conversation - 30+ audio messages transcribed by ChatGPT. Different tone than text: more vulnerable, rambling, exploratory. Bilal uses voice mode for coaching/thinking partnership, not just Q&A.
